English Item (Author's suggestion): I have trouble maintaining my attention at work.
dsm5_criteria: Often has difficulty sustaining attention in tasks or play activities (e.g., has difficulty remaining focused during lectures, conversations, or lengthy reading).

English Item (Author's suggestion): I have trouble staying focused during conversations
dsm5_criteria: Often has difficulty sustaining attention in tasks or play activities (e.g., has difficulty remaining focused during lectures, conversations, or lengthy reading).

English Item (Author's suggestion): My mind is often elsewhere, even when there is no obvious distraction
dsm5_criteria: Often does not seem to listen when spoken to directly (e.g., mind seems elsewhere, even in the absence of any obvious distraction).

English Item (Author's suggestion): I have difficulty completing my tasks (work, home)
dsm5_criteria: Often does not follow through on instructions and fails to finish schoolwork, chores, or duties in the workplace (e.g., starts tasks but quickly loses focus and is easily sidetracked).

English Item (Author's suggestion): I have difficulty staying focused during my activities (domestic, professional).
dsm5_criteria: Often does not follow through on instructions and fails to finish schoolwork, chores, or duties in the workplace (e.g., starts tasks but quickly loses focus and is easily sidetracked).

English Item (Author's suggestion): It is difficult for me to organize tasks that require several steps
dsm5_criteria: Often has difficulty organizing tasks and activities (e.g., difficulty managing sequential tasks, difficulty keeping materials and belongings in order, messy, disorganized work, has poor time management, fails to meet deadlines).

English Item (Author's suggestion): I tend to avoid tasks that require sustained mental effort (homework at school, writing a report ....)
dsm5_criteria: Often avoids, dislikes, or is reluctant to engage in tasks that require sustained mental effort (e.g., schoolwork or homework, for older adolescents and adults, preparing reports, completing forms, reviewing lengthy papers).

English Item (Author's suggestion): I often lose things I need for my work
dsm5_criteria: Often loses things necessary for tasks or activities (e.g., school materials, pencils, books, tools, wallets, keys, paperwork, eyeglasses, mobile telephones).

English Item (Author's suggestion): I am easily distracted by my environment
dsm5_criteria: Is often easily distracted by extraneous stimuli (for older adolescents and adults, may include unrelated thoughts).

English Item (Author's suggestion): I often leave my seat unnecessarily during a meeting
dsm5_criteria: Often leaves seat in situations when remaining seated is expected (e.g., leaves his or her place in the classroom, in the office or other workplace, or in other situations that require remaining in place).

English Item (Author's suggestion): I often leave my seat unnecessarily at work.
dsm5_criteria: Often leaves seat in situations when remaining seated is expected (e.g., leaves his or her place in the classroom, in the office or other workplace, or in other situations that require remaining in place).

English Item (Author's suggestion): The people around me think that I am a restless person.
dsm5_criteria: Often runs about or climbs in situations where it is inappropriate. (Note: In adolescents or adults, may be limited to feeling restless.)

English Item (Author's suggestion): It's hard for me to sit still for any length of time.
dsm5_criteria: Is often “on the go,” acting as if “driven by a motor” (e.g., is unable to be or uncomfortable being still for extended time, as in restaurants, meetings, may be experienced by others as being restless or difficult to keep up with).

English Item (Author's suggestion): I find it difficult to wait my turn in a conversation before speaking.
dsm5_criteria: Often blurts out an answer before a question has been completed (e.g., completes people’s sentences, cannot wait for turn in conversation).

English Item (Author's suggestion): I often impose myself in conversations.
dsm5_criteria: Often interrupts or intrudes on others (e.g., butts into conversations, games, or activities, may start using other people’s things without asking or receiving permission, for adolescents and adults, may intrude into or take over what others are doing).
